Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Some superheros can move
faster than the wind. The men in Apollo 10 reached a record-breaking speed of around 25,000 miles per hour when the shuttle re-entered the Earth's atmosphere in 1969. Wouldn't we save a lot of time to be able to move that fast? But what's the catch? Air is not empty. Elements like oxygen and nitrogen, even countless dust particles, make up the air around us. When we move past these things in the air, we're rubbing against them and creating a lot of friction, which results in heat. Just like rubbing your hands
together warms them up or rubbing two sticks together makes fire, the faster objects rub together, the more heat is generated. So, if we're running
at 25,000 miles per hour, the heat from friction
would burn our faces off. Even if we somehow withstood the heat, the sand and dirt in the air would still scrape us up with millions of tiny cuts all happening at the same time. Ever seen the front bumper
or grill of a truck? What do you think all the birds
and bugs would do to your open eyes or exposed skin? Okay, so you'll wear a mask to avoid destroying your face. But what about people in buildings between you and your destination? It takes us approximately
one-fifth of a second to react to what we see. By the time we see what is ahead of us and react to it - time times velocity equals distance equals one-fifth of a second times 25,000 miles per hour equals 1.4 miles - we would have gone past it or through it by over a mile. We're either going to kill ourselves by crashing into the nearest
wall at super speed or, worse, if we're indestructible, we've essentially turned
our bodies into missiles that destroy everything in our path. So, long distance travel
at 25,000 miles per hour would leave us burning up, covered in bugs, and leaves no time to react. What about short bursts to a location we can see with no obstacles in between? Okay, let's say a bullet is about to hit a beautiful
damsel in distress. So, our hero swoops in at super speed, grabs her, and carries her to safety. That sounds very romantic, but, in reality, that girl
will probably suffer more damage from the hero than the bullet if he moved her at super speed. Newton's First Law of Motion
deals with inertia, which is the resistance to a change in its state of motion. So, an object will continue moving or staying at the same place unless something changes it. Acceleration is the rate
the velocity changes over time. When the girl at rest, velocity equals zero miles per hour, begins accelerating to reach
the speed within seconds, velocity increases rapidly to 25,000 miles per hour, her brain would crash
into the side of her skull. And, when she stops suddenly, velocity decreases rapidly
back to zero miles per hour, her brain would crash
into the other side of her skull, turning her brain into mush. The brain is too fragile
to handle the sudden movement. So is every part of her
body, for that matter. Remember, it's not the speed
that causes the damage because the astronauts survived Apollo 10, it's the acceleration or sudden stop that causes our internal organs to crash into the front of our bodies the way we move forward in a bus when the driver slams on the brakes. What the hero did to the girl is mathematically the same
as running her over with a space shuttle at maximum speed. She probably died instantly
at the point of impact. He's going to owe this poor
girl's family an apology and a big fat compensation check. Oh, and possibly face jail time. Doctors have to carry liability insurance just in case they make a mistake
and hurt their patients. I wonder how much superhero
insurance policy would cost. Now, which superpower physics lesson will you explore next? Shifting body size and content, super speed, flight, super strength, immortality, and invisibility.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is NOT a common component found in the air around us?
Options: A. Nitrogen, B. Sodium, C. Oxygen, D. Dust particles
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the record-breaking speed achieved by the men in Apollo 10 in 1969? Options: A. 10,000 miles per hour, B. 25,000 miles per hour, C. 50,000 miles per hour, D. 100,000 miles per hour Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary cause of heat generated when moving at high speeds through the air? Options: A. Friction between the object and air particles, B. Air resistance, C. Gravity, D. Inertia Correct Option: None
Question 3: What would happen to a person's face if they were running at 25,000 miles per hour? Options: A. It would experience a gentle breeze, B. It would be protected by the air particles, C. It would burn due to friction, D. It would freeze due to the high speed Correct Option: None
Question 4: According to Newton's First Law of Motion, what is the resistance to a change in an object's state of motion called? Options: A. Inertia, B. Acceleration, C. Velocity, D. Friction Correct Option: None
Question 5: What would happen to a person's brain if they were accelerated to 25,000 miles per hour and then suddenly stopped? Options: A. It would experience no damage, B. It would crash into the side of the skull, C. It would expand in size, D. It would contract in size Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the primary cause of damage to a person's internal organs when moving at high speeds? Options: A. Speed, B. Acceleration or sudden stop, C. Air resistance, D. Gravity Correct Option: None
Question 7: How long does it take for a person to react to what they see? Options: A. 1 second, B. 1/5 of a second, C. 1 minute, D. 1 hour Correct Option: None
Question 8: What would happen to a person if they were moved at super speed by a hero trying to save them? Options: A. They would be safely transported to their destination, B. They would experience no damage, C. They would probably suffer more damage from the hero than the original threat, D. They would be unaffected by the movement Correct Option: None
Question 9: Why do astronauts survive high-speed travel in space? Options: A. Because they are wearing protective gear, B. Because they are traveling in a vacuum, C. Because the acceleration and deceleration are gradual, D. Because they are indestructible Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the primary concern for a hero who moves at super speed and tries to save someone? Options: A. The hero's own safety, B. The safety of bystanders, C. The potential damage to the person being saved, D. The hero's liability insurance policy Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

Options: A. Nitrogen, B. Sodium, C. Oxygen, D. Dust particles

However, this exact question is not present in the generated MCQs. Among the provided generated MCQs, none directly match the ground truth MCQ. But if I had to choose one that is somewhat related to the topic of air and its components, I would select:

Matching Prompt:

**Transcript**:
Some superheros can move
faster than the wind. The men in Apollo 10 reached a record-breaking speed of around 25,000 miles per hour when the shuttle re-entered the Earth's atmosphere in 1969. Wouldn't we save a lot of time to be able to move that fast? But what's the catch? Air is not empty. Elements like oxygen and nitrogen, even countless dust particles, make up the air around us. When we move past these things in the air, we're rubbing against them and creating a lot of friction, which results in heat. Just like rubbing your hands
together warms them up or rubbing two sticks together makes fire, the faster objects rub together, the more heat is generated. So, if we're running
at 25,000 miles per hour, the heat from friction
would burn our faces off. Even if we somehow withstood the heat, the sand and dirt in the air would still scrape us up with millions of tiny cuts all happening at the same time. Ever seen the front bumper
or grill of a truck? What do you think all the birds
and bugs would do to your open eyes or exposed skin? Okay, so you'll wear a mask to avoid destroying your face. But what about people in buildings between you and your destination? It takes us approximately
one-fifth of a second to react to what we see. By the time we see what is ahead of us and react to it - time times velocity equals distance equals one-fifth of a second times 25,000 miles per hour equals 1.4 miles - we would have gone past it or through it by over a mile. We're either going to kill ourselves by crashing into the nearest
wall at super speed or, worse, if we're indestructible, we've essentially turned
our bodies into missiles that destroy everything in our path. So, long distance travel
at 25,000 miles per hour would leave us burning up, covered in bugs, and leaves no time to react. What about short bursts to a location we can see with no obstacles in between? Okay, let's say a bullet is about to hit a beautiful
damsel in distress. So, our hero swoops in at super speed, grabs her, and carries her to safety. That sounds very romantic, but, in reality, that girl
will probably suffer more damage from the hero than the bullet if he moved her at super speed. Newton's First Law of Motion
deals with inertia, which is the resistance to a change in its state of motion. So, an object will continue moving or staying at the same place unless something changes it. Acceleration is the rate
the velocity changes over time. When the girl at rest, velocity equals zero miles per hour, begins accelerating to reach
the speed within seconds, velocity increases rapidly to 25,000 miles per hour, her brain would crash
into the side of her skull. And, when she stops suddenly, velocity decreases rapidly
back to zero miles per hour, her brain would crash
into the other side of her skull, turning her brain into mush. The brain is too fragile

body, for that matter. Remember, it's not the speed
that causes the damage because the astronauts survived Apollo 10, it's the acceleration or sudden stop that causes our internal organs to crash into the front of our bodies the way we move forward in a bus when the driver slams on the brakes. What the hero did to the girl is mathematically the same
as running her over with a space shuttle at maximum speed. She probably died instantly
at the point of impact. He's going to owe this poor
girl's family an apology and a big fat compensation check. Oh, and possibly face jail time. Doctors have to carry liability insurance just in case they make a mistake
and hurt their patients. I wonder how much superhero
insurance policy would cost. Now, which superpower physics lesson will you explore next? Shifting body size and content, super speed, flight, super strength, immortality, and invisibility.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does friction create?
Options: A. Volume, B. Mass, C. Density, D. Heat
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever helped set a table and found yourself wondering where to place the forks? Or sat down to eat a restaurant and wondered which utensils to use? Well, here's some simple,
traditional etiquette tips on how to set a table. What would happen if you
set a table like this? It doesn't look good, and you have to clean up the mess before you can even start. Let's try another way. To start, use a placemat or tablecloth, but not both, so the dishes aren't
directly on the table. This is more about looks than etiquette, but it's rare to see nothing under a plate unless you're eating at a picnic table. Set out any flowers, candlesticks, or other decorations you like. Candles are usually only lit at night. Start with utensils for the main course, putting your dinner fork on the left and your dinner knife
on the right-hand side since these are the hands
we use them with. Here's a helpful tip: You always eat outside-in, so to set for salad, we'll put the salad fork to the outside of the dinner fork and the salad knife
to the outside of the dinner knife. We'll have salad first, then our main course. Notice, too, that the knife blades are both pointed toward the plate. This is an old tradition from a time when dinner
knives were quite sharp, and it was a sign of politeness
and nonaggression to keep them pointed
away from other diners. We might have some soup, and since soup usually comes first, the soup spoon goes outside the knives since we use our right hand to hold it. Here's another tip: Only set the table with what you'll need. If you're not eating soup, don't set a soup spoon. Now, for dessert, we'll have ice cream so we'll place the dessert up top since we don't need it for a little while. Notice that the bowl of the spool is pointing to the left. This way, when it's time to eat, you just slide it down and it's in the right spot. If you were having cake, you'd set a fork and flip it 180 degrees so it would be right side-up
on the left instead. Next we'll anchor
our setting with the plate. You can also serve from the kitchen then bring them to the table. The bread plate goes
up and to the left of the setting, and the butter knife goes
on the plate at an angle, again, with the blade pointing in. There's only one spot left, and that's for the drinks. Set the wine glass to the upper right, and then place the water glass
to the left of it at an angle. If you're like me and can never remember which goes where, think water, wine, w-a, w-i; a, i; they go left to right
in alphabetical order. Another tip: To remember left and right
with the bread and the drinks, think B-M-W like the car. B, your bread plate, is on the left; M, your meal, is in the middle, and W, your water, is on the right. Lastly, the napkin traditionally
goes to the left of the forks, though it's okay to put
it underneath them, too. For a fancier meal like this one that takes up a lot of space, we'll put it in the middle. Now we're ready to eat. Hopefully these tips will be helpful the next time you're asked
to help set the table or sit down at a fancy meal. Enjoy!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: On what side of the plate should you place the dinner knife?
Options: A. Left, B. Right, C. Above, D. Below
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the recommended way to start setting a table? Options: A. Use a placemat and tablecloth together, B. Use a placemat or tablecloth, but not both, C. Place the dishes directly on the table, D. Set out flowers and candlesticks first Correct Option: None
Question 2: Which of the following is a traditional etiquette tip for setting a table? Options: A. Placing the dinner fork on the right-hand side, B. Placing the dinner knife on the left-hand side, C. Pointing the knife blades toward the plate, D. Pointing the knife blades away from the plate Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the correct order for setting utensils for a meal that includes salad, main course, and soup? Options: A. Dinner fork, salad fork, soup spoon, B. Salad fork, dinner fork, soup spoon, C. Soup spoon, salad fork, dinner fork, D. Dinner fork, soup spoon, salad fork Correct Option: None
Question 4: Where should the bread plate be placed in a table setting? Options: A. Up and to the right of the setting, B. Up and to the left of the setting, C. Down and to the right of the setting, D. Down and to the left of the setting Correct Option: None
Question 5: How should the butter knife be placed on the bread plate? Options: A. With the blade pointing out, B. With the blade pointing in, C. At a 90-degree angle to the plate, D. Parallel to the plate Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is a helpful tip for remembering the order of the water glass and wine glass? Options: A. Think of the colors of the glasses, B. Think of the shapes of the glasses, C. Think of the alphabetical order of "water" and "wine", D. Think of the size of the glasses Correct Option: None
Question 7: Where should the napkin traditionally be placed in a table setting? Options: A. To the right of the forks, B. To the left of the forks, C. Underneath the forks, D. In the middle of the setting Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the purpose of setting the table with only what you'll need? Options: A. To save space, B. To reduce clutter, C. To follow traditional etiquette, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 9: How should the dessert spoon be placed in a table setting if you're having ice cream? Options: A. With the bowl of the spoon pointing to the right, B. With the bowl of the spoon pointing to the left, C. With the bowl of the spoon pointing up, D. With the bowl of the spoon pointing down Correct Option: None

Think of the shapes of the plates and glasses, C. Think of the alphabetical order of "bread", "meal", and "water", D. Think of the phrase "B-M-W" like the car Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever helped set a table and found yourself wondering where to place the forks? Or sat down to eat a restaurant and wondered which utensils to use? Well, here's some simple,
traditional etiquette tips on how to set a table. What would happen if you
set a table like this? It doesn't look good, and you have to clean up the mess before you can even start. Let's try another way. To start, use a placemat or tablecloth, but not both, so the dishes aren't
directly on the table. This is more about looks than etiquette, but it's rare to see nothing under a plate unless you're eating at a picnic table. Set out any flowers, candlesticks, or other decorations you like. Candles are usually only lit at night. Start with utensils for the main course, putting your dinner fork on the left and your dinner knife
on the right-hand side since these are the hands
we use them with. Here's a helpful tip: You always eat outside-in, so to set for salad, we'll put the salad fork to the outside of the dinner fork and the salad knife
to the outside of the dinner knife. We'll have salad first, then our main course. Notice, too, that the knife blades are both pointed toward the plate. This is an old tradition from a time when dinner
knives were quite sharp, and it was a sign of politeness
and nonaggression to keep them pointed
away from other diners. We might have some soup, and since soup usually comes first, the soup spoon goes outside the knives since we use our right hand to hold it. Here's another tip: Only set the table with what you'll need. If you're not eating soup, don't set a soup spoon. Now, for dessert, we'll have ice cream so we'll place the dessert up top since we don't need it for a little while. Notice that the bowl of the spool is pointing to the left. This way, when it's time to eat, you just slide it down and it's in the right spot. If you were having cake, you'd set a fork and flip it 180 degrees so it would be right side-up
on the left instead. Next we'll anchor
our setting with the plate. You can also serve from the kitchen then bring them to the table. The bread plate goes
up and to the left of the setting, and the butter knife goes
on the plate at an angle, again, with the blade pointing in. There's only one spot left, and that's for the drinks. Set the wine glass to the upper right, and then place the water glass
to the left of it at an angle. If you're like me and can never remember which goes where, think water, wine, w-a, w-i; a, i; they go left to right
in alphabetical order. Another tip: To remember left and right
with the bread and the drinks, think B-M-W like the car. B, your bread plate, is on the left; M, your meal, is in the middle, and W, your water, is on the right. Lastly, the napkin traditionally
goes to the left of the forks, though it's okay to put
it underneath them, too. For a fancier meal like this one that takes up a lot of space, we'll put it in the middle. Now we're ready to eat. Hopefully these tips will be helpful the next time you're asked
to help set the table or sit down at a fancy meal. Enjoy!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which way do the knives point when placed on the table or the bread plate?
Options: A. Away from the person using them (away from the plate), B. Away from other diners at the table (toward the plate), C. The bread knife always faced the opposite direction of the dinner and salad knives, D. The salad and dinner knives are always placed at a 180 degree angle of each other, while the bread knife is arbitrarily placed near or on the bread plate
Correct Option: B

Question 2: Which of the following is a traditional etiquette tip for setting a table? Options: A. Placing the dinner fork on the right-hand side, B. Salad fork, dinner fork, soup spoon, C. Soup spoon, salad fork, dinner fork, D. Dinner fork, soup spoon, salad fork Correct Option: None
Question 4: Where should the bread plate be placed in a table setting? Options: A. Up and to the right of the setting, B. Up and to the left of the setting, C. Down and to the right of the setting, D. Down and to the left of the setting Correct Option: None
Question 5: How should the butter knife be placed on the bread plate? Options: A. With the blade pointing out, B. With the blade pointing in, C. At a 90-degree angle to the plate, D. Parallel to the plate Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is a helpful tip for remembering the order of the water glass and wine glass? Options: A. Think of the colors of the glasses, B. Think of the shapes of the glasses, C. Think of the alphabetical order of "water" and "wine", D. Think of the size of the glasses Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever helped set a table and found yourself wondering where to place the forks? Or sat down to eat a restaurant and wondered which utensils to use? Well, here's some simple,
traditional etiquette tips on how to set a table. What would happen if you
set a table like this? It doesn't look good, and you have to clean up the mess before you can even start. Let's try another way. To start, use a placemat or tablecloth, but not both, so the dishes aren't
directly on the table. This is more about looks than etiquette, but it's rare to see nothing under a plate unless you're eating at a picnic table. Set out any flowers, candlesticks, or other decorations you like. Candles are usually only lit at night. Start with utensils for the main course, putting your dinner fork on the left and your dinner knife
on the right-hand side since these are the hands
we use them with. Here's a helpful tip: You always eat outside-in, so to set for salad, we'll put the salad fork to the outside of the dinner fork and the salad knife
to the outside of the dinner knife. We'll have salad first, then our main course. Notice, too, that the knife blades are both pointed toward the plate. This is an old tradition from a time when dinner
knives were quite sharp, and it was a sign of politeness
and nonaggression to keep them pointed
away from other diners. We might have some soup, and since soup usually comes first, the soup spoon goes outside the knives since we use our right hand to hold it. Here's another tip: Only set the table with what you'll need. If you're not eating soup, don't set a soup spoon. Now, for dessert, we'll have ice cream so we'll place the dessert up top since we don't need it for a little while. Notice that the bowl of the spool is pointing to the left. This way, when it's time to eat, you just slide it down and it's in the right spot. If you were having cake, you'd set a fork and flip it 180 degrees so it would be right side-up
on the left instead. Next we'll anchor
our setting with the plate. You can also serve from the kitchen then bring them to the table. The bread plate goes
up and to the left of the setting, and the butter knife goes
on the plate at an angle, again, with the blade pointing in. There's only one spot left, and that's for the drinks. Set the wine glass to the upper right, and then place the water glass
to the left of it at an angle. If you're like me and can never remember which goes where, think water, wine, w-a, w-i; a, i; they go left to right
in alphabetical order. Another tip: To remember left and right
with the bread and the drinks, think B-M-W like the car. B, your bread plate, is on the left; M, your meal, is in the middle, and W, your water, is on the right. Lastly, the napkin traditionally
goes to the left of the forks, though it's okay to put
it underneath them, too. For a fancier meal like this one that takes up a lot of space, we'll put it in the middle. Now we're ready to eat. Hopefully these tips will be helpful the next time you're asked
to help set the table or sit down at a fancy meal. Enjoy!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Water, wine ("wa" and "wi"). A, I. They go in order alphabetically from left to right. The water is always placed to the left of the wine. What's another good acronym?
Options: A. BMW (bread, meal, water), B. GLOW (goblet left of water), C. JFK (Just put the Fork before the Knife), D. SPEW (from left to right, spoon, plate, everything else, water)
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Think of all the food made
in the world each year. Hard to picture? Then, imagine that you
are all of humanity, and on a plate in front of you is the one lovely annual
meal you make for yourself. You did all sorts of work putting
that meal on your table. You must be eager to consume
the fruits of your labor. And the vegetables and meats and waffles of your labor, too, right? Well, oddly enough, a third of that meal ends up in the trash. A third of the food we eat globally, an estimated 1.3 billion tons ends up as waste. All the work we put into producing
that food is wasted. And what's worse, it costs us. America alone spends an estimated 165 billion dollars a year managing food waste. We're wasting food, energy, and money. Perhaps worst of all, we're wasting the chance to change, to make the system of food
consumption more efficient. If you want to bring on that change, you should know about a humble yet diligent and ever-so-crucial ally: the worm. Worms convert organic waste and other compostable products
into natural fertilizers. Up to 75% of what we put
in the waste stream can become food and bedding material for vermicomposting. You can create a worm bin in your own home to see the composting process in action. First off, you need worms and not your typical earthworms. You need redworms, eisenia foetida, the species responsible for most vermicomposting in North America. These red wigglers are surface dwellers who don't burrow too deep, they're optimal feeders
around room temperature, and they're well-suited
to converting organic waste into usable fertilizer. Now, your worms might be vermin, but they need a comfortable
space to live and work: some bedding materials, either shredded paper or cardboard, some moisture, and, of course, food, mainly, your leftovers, slightly decomposed table scraps. The worms break down food waste and other organic matter into castings, a fancy synonym for worm poop. Their excrement is absolutely
teeming with microbes, which continue the decomposition process, making all those once-wasted nutrients available again as fertilizer. The timeline for the whole process varies depending on the quantity of worms, the temperature, and how much waste is added to the bin. And there's another timeline to consider. In a healthy worm-bin habitat, worm reproduction will occur when the wigglers become sexually mature, indicated by an elongation of the segments into a bulbous structure. Three-month old wigglers can produce two to three semi-translucent
yellow worm cocoons a week. You thought only moths and butterflies come out of cocoons? Well, we can't all be majestic. It takes around 11 weeks
for new babies to hatch. When your bin seems to be full
of living vermicelli noodles, it's time to share
the bounty with your friends and start a vermicompost club. Or keep those worms to yourself and start a business. Vermicomposting isn't confined only to small worm bins, it's an emerging
entrepreneurial enterprise. Large-scale facilities convert bulk organic waste and even manure into rich, black castings
called black gold. Its value as a soil
additive is unparalleled, and it can help plants
resist harmful pathogens. The lack of available land
in urban environments, coupled with growing interest
in smaller-scale farming means there is a market
for vermicomposting. Many communities use composting as part of zero-waste strategies, and they can sell
their worm-eaten table scraps to local farms, hungry
for rich fertilizer. So, instead of wasting money, dumping wasted food in landfills, we can remake waste into an asset, putting it back into our food system to make it more sustainable, all with the help of the humble worm, the tiny organism that can help us change the way we look
at food's place in our lives and our place in the world, as long as we give the little guy a place at our table. Well, not an actual seat at the table. A bin in the shed is fine.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the term used to describe the conversion of organic materials into valuable worm castings?
Options: A. Vermiculture, B. Vermicompost, C. Vermicelli, D. Thermophillic composting
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the world's food production ends up as waste? Options: A. 10%, B. 25%, C. 33%, D. 50% Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the estimated annual cost of managing food waste in America? Options: A. 100 billion dollars, B. 165 billion dollars, C. 200 billion dollars, D. 250 billion dollars Correct Option: None
Question 3: What type of worms are best suited for vermicomposting in North America? Options: A. Earthworms, B. Redworms (Eisenia foetida), C. Nightcrawlers, D. Flatworms Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the primary role of worms in the vermicomposting process? Options: A. To consume non-organic waste, B. To convert organic waste into natural fertilizers, C. To aerate the soil, D. To repel pests Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the ideal temperature for redworms to thrive in a worm bin? Options: A. Freezing temperatures, B. Room temperature, C. High temperatures, D. Fluctuating temperatures Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the byproduct of worm digestion that is rich in microbes and nutrients? Options: A. Castings (worm poop), B. Bedding material, C. Organic waste, D. Fertilizer pellets Correct Option: None
Question 7: How often can three-month-old redworms produce worm cocoons? Options: A. Daily, B. Weekly, C. Monthly, D. Two to three cocoons a week Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the approximate time it takes for new worms to hatch from cocoons? Options: A. 5 weeks, B. 11 weeks, C. 20 weeks, D. 30 weeks Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the term used to describe large-scale vermicomposting facilities that produce rich, black castings? Options: A. Black gold mining, B. Vermicomposting factories, C. Black gold production, D. Large-scale composting Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is one of the benefits of using vermicompost as a soil additive? Options: A. It increases soil acidity, B. It decreases soil fertility, C. It helps plants resist harmful pathogens, D. It reduces soil aeration Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4: What is the primary role of worms in the vermicomposting process? Options: A. To consume non-organic waste, B. To convert organic waste into natural fertilizers, C. To aerate the soil, D. To repel pests.

However, this question does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ. A more suitable match would be a generated MCQ that explicitly mentions "vermicompost" or "worm castings." Since none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ, the closest match is:

Question 6: What is the byproduct of worm digestion that is rich in microbes and nutrients? Options: A. Castings (worm poop), B. Bedding material, C. Organic waste, D. Fertilizer pellets.

This question is related to vermicomposting and worm castings, making it the most similar generated MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 6

their worm-eaten table scraps to local farms, hungry
for rich fertilizer. So, instead of wasting money, dumping wasted food in landfills, we can remake waste into an asset, putting it back into our food system to make it more sustainable, all with the help of the humble worm, the tiny organism that can help us change the way we look
at food's place in our lives and our place in the world, as long as we give the little guy a place at our table. Well, not an actual seat at the table. A bin in the shed is fine.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The term ________ is synonymous with â€œworm poopâ€ and is often referred to as â€œBlack Goldâ€?
Options: A. Bulbous Glands, B. Wigglers, C. Vermicelli, D. Bedding Material, E. Castings
Correct Option: E

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Think of all the food made
in the world each year. Hard to picture? Then, imagine that you
are all of humanity, and on a plate in front of you is the one lovely annual
meal you make for yourself. You did all sorts of work putting
that meal on your table. You must be eager to consume
the fruits of your labor. And the vegetables and meats and waffles of your labor, too, right? Well, oddly enough, a third of that meal ends up in the trash. A third of the food we eat globally, an estimated 1.3 billion tons ends up as waste. All the work we put into producing
that food is wasted. And what's worse, it costs us. America alone spends an estimated 165 billion dollars a year managing food waste. We're wasting food, energy, and money. Perhaps worst of all, we're wasting the chance to change, to make the system of food
consumption more efficient. If you want to bring on that change, you should know about a humble yet diligent and ever-so-crucial ally: the worm. Worms convert organic waste and other compostable products
into natural fertilizers. Up to 75% of what we put
in the waste stream can become food and bedding material for vermicomposting. You can create a worm bin in your own home to see the composting process in action. First off, you need worms and not your typical earthworms. You need redworms, eisenia foetida, the species responsible for most vermicomposting in North America. These red wigglers are surface dwellers who don't burrow too deep, they're optimal feeders
around room temperature, and they're well-suited
to converting organic waste into usable fertilizer. Now, your worms might be vermin, but they need a comfortable
space to live and work: some bedding materials, either shredded paper or cardboard, some moisture, and, of course, food, mainly, your leftovers, slightly decomposed table scraps. The worms break down food waste and other organic matter into castings, a fancy synonym for worm poop. Their excrement is absolutely
teeming with microbes, which continue the decomposition process, making all those once-wasted nutrients available again as fertilizer. The timeline for the whole process varies depending on the quantity of worms, the temperature, and how much waste is added to the bin. And there's another timeline to consider. In a healthy worm-bin habitat, worm reproduction will occur when the wigglers become sexually mature, indicated by an elongation of the segments into a bulbous structure. Three-month old wigglers can produce two to three semi-translucent
yellow worm cocoons a week. You thought only moths and butterflies come out of cocoons? Well, we can't all be majestic. It takes around 11 weeks
for new babies to hatch. When your bin seems to be full
of living vermicelli noodles, it's time to share
the bounty with your friends and start a vermicompost club. Or keep those worms to yourself and start a business. Vermicomposting isn't confined only to small worm bins, it's an emerging
entrepreneurial enterprise. Large-scale facilities convert bulk organic waste and even manure into rich, black castings
called black gold. Its value as a soil
additive is unparalleled, and it can help plants
resist harmful pathogens. The lack of available land
in urban environments, coupled with growing interest
in smaller-scale farming means there is a market
for vermicomposting. Many communities use composting as part of zero-waste strategies, and they can sell
their worm-eaten table scraps to local farms, hungry
for rich fertilizer. So, instead of wasting money, dumping wasted food in landfills, we can remake waste into an asset, putting it back into our food system to make it more sustainable, all with the help of the humble worm, the tiny organism that can help us change the way we look
at food's place in our lives and our place in the world, as long as we give the little guy a place at our table. Well, not an actual seat at the table. A bin in the shed is fine.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: You should use earthworms collected from your yard to start vermicomposting efforts at your own home.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What is at the center of the universe? It's an essential question that humans have
been wondering about for centuries. But the journey toward an answer has been a strange one. If you wanted to know
the answer to this question in third century B.C.E. Greece, you might look up at the night sky and trust what you see. That's what Aristotle, THE guy to ask back then, did. He thought that since we're
on Earth, looking up, it must be the center, right? For him, the sphere of the world was made up of four elements: Earth, water, air, and fire. These elements shifted around a nested set of solid crystalline spheres. Each of the wandering stars, the planets, had their own crystal sphere. The rest of the universe
and all of its stars were on the last crystal sphere. If you watch the sky change over time, you could see that this idea worked fine at explaining the motion you saw. For centuries, this
was central to how Europe and the Islamic world saw the universe. But in 1543, a guy named Copernicus proposed a different model. He believed that the sun was at the center of the universe. This radically new idea was hard for a lot of people to accept. After all, Aristotle's ideas made sense with what they could see, and they were pretty flattering to humans. But a series of subsequent discoveries made the sun-centric model hard to ignore. First, Johannes Kepler pointed out that orbits aren't perfect
circles or spheres. Then, Galileo's telescope caught Jupiter's moons orbiting around Jupiter, totally ignoring Earth. And then, Newton proposed the theory
of universal gravitation, demonstrating that all objects
are pulling on each other. Eventually, we had to let go of the idea that we were at the center
of the universe. Shortly after Copernicus, in the 1580s, an Italian friar, Giordano Bruno, suggested the stars were suns that likely had their own planets and that the universe was infinite. This idea didn't go over well. Bruno was burned at the stake
for his radical suggestion. Centuries later,
the philosopher Rene Descartes proposed that the universe
was a series of whirlpools, which he called vortices, and that each star
was at the center of a whirlpool. In time, we realized there
were far more stars than Aristotle ever dreamed. As astronomers like William Herschel got more and more advanced telescopes, it became clear that our sun is actually one of many stars inside the Milky Way. And those smudges we see in the night sky? They're other galaxies, just as vast as our Milky Way home. Maybe we're farther from the center
than we ever realized. In the 1920s, astronomers
studying the nebuli wanted to figure out how they were moving. Based on the Doppler Effect, they expected to see blue shift for objects moving toward us, and red shift for ones moving away. But all they saw was a red shift. Everything was moving away from us, fast. This observation
is one of the pieces of evidence for what we now call the Big Bang Theory. According to this theory, all matter in the universe was once a singular,
infinitely dense particle. In a sense, our piece of the universe was once at the center. But this theory eliminates
the whole idea of a center since there can't be a center
to an infinite universe. The Big Bang wasn't just
an explosion in space; it was an explosion of space. What each new discovery proves is that while our observations
are limited, our ability to speculate and dream of what's out there isn't. What we think we know today
can change tomorrow. As with many of the thinkers we just met, sometimes our wildest guesses lead to wonderful and humbling answers and propel us toward even more
perplexing questions.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What did Aristotle and most of the ancient Greeks think was at the center of the universe?
Options: A. The Sun, B. The Earth, C. The Milky Way, D. The Moon
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the ancient Greek philosopher that believed Earth was at the center of the universe? Options: A. Plato, B. Socrates, C. Aristotle, D. Epicurus Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was the basis of Aristotle's model of the universe? Options: A. The universe is infinite and has no center, B. The universe is made up of four elements: Earth, water, air, and fire, C. The universe is made up of seven elements: Earth, water, air, fire, and three unknown elements, D. The universe is made up of two elements: Earth and water Correct Option: None
Question 3: Who proposed the sun-centric model of the universe in 1543? Options: A. Galileo, B. Copernicus, C. Johannes Kepler, D. Isaac Newton Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the significance of Galileo's observation of Jupiter's moons? Options: A. It proved that Earth is at the center of the universe, B. It proved that the sun is at the center of the universe, C. It showed that the moons were orbiting around Jupiter, not Earth, D. It showed that the moons were orbiting around Earth, not Jupiter Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the theory proposed by Newton that explains the motion of objects in the universe? Options: A. The theory of universal gravitation, B. The theory of relativity, C. The theory of evolution, D. The theory of plate tectonics Correct Option: None
Question 6: Conceptual Question: What is the main difference between Aristotle's model of the universe and the sun-centric model? Options: A. Aristotle's model is based on observations, while the sun-centric model is based on speculation, B. Aristotle's model places Earth at the center, while the sun-centric model places the sun at the center, C. Aristotle's model is based on the four elements, while the sun-centric model is based on the seven elements, D. Aristotle's model is infinite, while the sun-centric model is finite Correct Option: None
Question 7: Application Question: If you were an astronomer in the 16th century, what would be the implications of accepting the sun-centric model of the universe? Options: A. It would mean that Earth is no longer at the center of the universe, B. It would mean that the sun is no longer at the center of the universe, C. It would mean that the universe is infinite, D. It would mean that the universe is finite Correct Option: None
Question 8: Analytical Question: What is the significance of the red shift observed in the nebuli in the 1920s? Options: A. It proved that the universe is infinite, B. It proved that the universe is finite, C. It showed that the nebuli are moving away from us, D. It showed that the nebuli are moving towards us Correct Option: None

The universe is made up of four elements: Earth, water, air, and fire, D. The universe is made up of seven elements: Earth, water, air, fire, and three unknown elements Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What is at the center of the universe? It's an essential question that humans have
been wondering about for centuries. But the journey toward an answer has been a strange one. If you wanted to know
the answer to this question in third century B.C.E. Greece, you might look up at the night sky and trust what you see. That's what Aristotle, THE guy to ask back then, did. He thought that since we're
on Earth, looking up, it must be the center, right? For him, the sphere of the world was made up of four elements: Earth, water, air, and fire. These elements shifted around a nested set of solid crystalline spheres. Each of the wandering stars, the planets, had their own crystal sphere. The rest of the universe
and all of its stars were on the last crystal sphere. If you watch the sky change over time, you could see that this idea worked fine at explaining the motion you saw. For centuries, this
was central to how Europe and the Islamic world saw the universe. But in 1543, a guy named Copernicus proposed a different model. He believed that the sun was at the center of the universe. This radically new idea was hard for a lot of people to accept. After all, Aristotle's ideas made sense with what they could see, and they were pretty flattering to humans. But a series of subsequent discoveries made the sun-centric model hard to ignore. First, Johannes Kepler pointed out that orbits aren't perfect
circles or spheres. Then, Galileo's telescope caught Jupiter's moons orbiting around Jupiter, totally ignoring Earth. And then, Newton proposed the theory
of universal gravitation, demonstrating that all objects
are pulling on each other. Eventually, we had to let go of the idea that we were at the center
of the universe. Shortly after Copernicus, in the 1580s, an Italian friar, Giordano Bruno, suggested the stars were suns that likely had their own planets and that the universe was infinite. This idea didn't go over well. Bruno was burned at the stake
for his radical suggestion. Centuries later,
the philosopher Rene Descartes proposed that the universe
was a series of whirlpools, which he called vortices, and that each star
was at the center of a whirlpool. In time, we realized there
were far more stars than Aristotle ever dreamed. As astronomers like William Herschel got more and more advanced telescopes, it became clear that our sun is actually one of many stars inside the Milky Way. And those smudges we see in the night sky? They're other galaxies, just as vast as our Milky Way home. Maybe we're farther from the center
than we ever realized. In the 1920s, astronomers
studying the nebuli wanted to figure out how they were moving. Based on the Doppler Effect, they expected to see blue shift for objects moving toward us, and red shift for ones moving away. But all they saw was a red shift. Everything was moving away from us, fast. This observation
is one of the pieces of evidence for what we now call the Big Bang Theory. According to this theory, all matter in the universe was once a singular,
infinitely dense particle. In a sense, our piece of the universe was once at the center. But this theory eliminates
the whole idea of a center since there can't be a center
to an infinite universe. The Big Bang wasn't just
an explosion in space; it was an explosion of space. What each new discovery proves is that while our observations
are limited, our ability to speculate and dream of what's out there isn't. What we think we know today
can change tomorrow. As with many of the thinkers we just met, sometimes our wildest guesses lead to wonderful and humbling answers and propel us toward even more
perplexing questions.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: All of the following scientific work contributed to the adoption of a sun-centered understanding of the solar system, except for one. Which of the following did not factor into adopting a sun-centered model?
Options: A. Galileoâ€™s telescope observations of the moons of Jupiter, B. Johannes Keplerâ€™s work showing that the orbits of the planets are elliptical and not circular, C. Isaac Newtonâ€™s development of the universal theory of gravitation, D. William Herschelâ€™s observations of nebulae
Correct Option: D

**Transcript**:
What is at the center of the universe? It's an essential question that humans have
been wondering about for centuries. But the journey toward an answer has been a strange one. If you wanted to know
the answer to this question in third century B.C.E. Greece, you might look up at the night sky and trust what you see. That's what Aristotle, THE guy to ask back then, did. He thought that since we're
on Earth, looking up, it must be the center, right? For him, the sphere of the world was made up of four elements: Earth, water, air, and fire. These elements shifted around a nested set of solid crystalline spheres. Each of the wandering stars, the planets, had their own crystal sphere. The rest of the universe
and all of its stars were on the last crystal sphere. If you watch the sky change over time, you could see that this idea worked fine at explaining the motion you saw. For centuries, this
was central to how Europe and the Islamic world saw the universe. But in 1543, a guy named Copernicus proposed a different model. He believed that the sun was at the center of the universe. This radically new idea was hard for a lot of people to accept. After all, Aristotle's ideas made sense with what they could see, and they were pretty flattering to humans. But a series of subsequent discoveries made the sun-centric model hard to ignore. First, Johannes Kepler pointed out that orbits aren't perfect
circles or spheres. Then, Galileo's telescope caught Jupiter's moons orbiting around Jupiter, totally ignoring Earth. And then, Newton proposed the theory
of universal gravitation, demonstrating that all objects
are pulling on each other. Eventually, we had to let go of the idea that we were at the center
of the universe. Shortly after Copernicus, in the 1580s, an Italian friar, Giordano Bruno, suggested the stars were suns that likely had their own planets and that the universe was infinite. This idea didn't go over well. Bruno was burned at the stake
for his radical suggestion. Centuries later,
the philosopher Rene Descartes proposed that the universe
was a series of whirlpools, which he called vortices, and that each star
was at the center of a whirlpool. In time, we realized there
were far more stars than Aristotle ever dreamed. As astronomers like William Herschel got more and more advanced telescopes, it became clear that our sun is actually one of many stars inside the Milky Way. And those smudges we see in the night sky? They're other galaxies, just as vast as our Milky Way home. Maybe we're farther from the center
than we ever realized. In the 1920s, astronomers
studying the nebuli wanted to figure out how they were moving. Based on the Doppler Effect, they expected to see blue shift for objects moving toward us, and red shift for ones moving away. But all they saw was a red shift. Everything was moving away from us, fast. This observation
is one of the pieces of evidence for what we now call the Big Bang Theory. According to this theory, all matter in the universe was once a singular,
infinitely dense particle. In a sense, our piece of the universe was once at the center. But this theory eliminates
the whole idea of a center since there can't be a center
to an infinite universe. The Big Bang wasn't just
an explosion in space; it was an explosion of space. What each new discovery proves is that while our observations
are limited, our ability to speculate and dream of what's out there isn't. What we think we know today
can change tomorrow. As with many of the thinkers we just met, sometimes our wildest guesses lead to wonderful and humbling answers and propel us toward even more
perplexing questions.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is not true about the Doppler effect?
Options: A. Objects moving toward us shift blue, objects moving away shift red., B. Nearly all the galaxies we can observe are shifted red., C. Objects moving toward us shift red, and objects moving away from us shift blue., D. Our observations, combined with the Doppler effect, suggest that nearly all the galaxies are moving away from us.
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Today lots of girls play sports. But, for a long time,
girls were not encouraged to kick, throw, run, jump, shoot, slide, or hit like boys. So, why did things change? And how much have they changed? Are girls and boys treated equally when it comes to sports? To begin to answer these questions, we have to look back. In 1972, Congress passed
a law called Title IX, which protected girls and women from discrimination in schools, colleges, and universities. This included discrimination
in school-sponsored sports. At that time, only 15%
of college athletes were women, and in high schools, only 7% of athletes were girls. Female athletes didn't get
a lot of support either and often had to provide
their own uniforms and equipment. It was Title IX that forced
school administrators to make sports more equal. But what does equal mean in sports? The government developed rules to measure equality
under two general categories: participation and treatment. In the early days of Title IX, the number of girls
playing sports was so low that it would have been very difficult for schools to suddenly provide
exactly the same number of opportunities for girls and boys. Instead, the government wrote rules that gave schools three options, or tests, to demonstrate fairness
in opportunities for girls. The three tests are proportionality, progress, and satisfied interests. A school can pick which test to follow. Proportionality means
that girls should receive the same percentage
of athletic opportunities as the percentage of girls
in the student body. So, if 51% of students are girls, then girls should have approximately 51% of the opportunities to play sports. The second test, progress, requires schools to make up for the days when girls had fewer opportunities by adding new sports for girls
on a regular basis. The third test asks if girls interested in athletics are satisfied. Under this test, a school
must regularly ask female students what sports
they are interested in and also take into consideration
the popularity of certain sports in the area where the school is located. It must, then, add teams according
to the girls' interests. Another important part of Title IX is that it doesn't just look at how many athletic opportunities
are available to each sex but whether those opportunities
are of equal quality. Specifically, Title IX requires equality between boys and girls teams for things like equipment and supplies, publicity, the scheduling of games
and practice times, and the quality and number of coaches. Girls should also have equal access to locker rooms, practice spaces,
and competitive facilities, as well as medical services. So, if the best time to play
basketball is on Friday nights because that's when
most parents and fans can come, then the girls and boys teams should take turns playing on Friday night. If boys teams play
in a stadium with lights, scoreboards, and concession stands, then girls teams must have
the same opportunity, either by sharing those facilities or getting their own of equal quality. But, as we all know, just because a law exists doesn't mean that everybody follows it. School officials are responsible for making sure there
is fairness in sports, but you can help, too, by keeping an eye on your own school. Look around. Are there a lot more boys
than girls who play sports? Is the boys' soccer field
better than the girls'? Are athletic trainers available
to all teams equally? Does the baseball team get
new uniforms every year, while the softball team gets
them every three years? If you think there might be
inequality in your schools, you can approach a school administrator, a parent, or the Office of Civil Rights, a government agency
that makes sure schools comply with Title IX because equality
is important for everyone, both on the field and off.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: To what activities does Title IX apply?
Options: A. Professional, Olympic, college, and scholastic sports, B. College and scholastic sports, C. All activities of schools and colleges and that receive federal funding, D. Classroom activities of schools and colleges and that receive federal funding
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What law was passed by Congress in 1972 to protect girls and women from discrimination in schools, colleges, and universities? Options: A. Title VII, B. Title IX, C. Title X, D. Title XI Correct Option: None
Question 2: What percentage of college athletes were women before the passage of Title IX? Options: A. 10%, B. 15%, C. 20%, D. 25% Correct Option: None
Question 3: What are the two general categories used to measure equality under Title IX? Options: A. Participation and funding, B. Participation and treatment, C. Funding and treatment, D. Funding and opportunities Correct Option: None
Question 4: What are the three tests used to demonstrate fairness in opportunities for girls under Title IX? Options: A. Proportionality, progress, and satisfied interests, B. Proportionality, equality, and fairness, C. Progress, equality, and satisfied interests, D. Proportionality, progress, and equality Correct Option: None
Question 5: What does the proportionality test require under Title IX? Options: A. That girls receive the same number of athletic opportunities as boys, B. That girls receive the same percentage of athletic opportunities as the percentage of girls in the student body, C. That girls receive more athletic opportunities than boys, D. That girls receive fewer athletic opportunities than boys Correct Option: None
Question 6: What does the progress test require under Title IX? Options: A. That schools make up for past inequalities by adding new sports for girls on a regular basis, B. That schools provide the same number of athletic opportunities for girls and boys, C. That schools provide more athletic opportunities for girls than boys, D. That schools provide fewer athletic opportunities for girls than boys Correct Option: None
Question 7: What does Title IX require in terms of equipment and supplies for boys and girls teams? Options: A. That boys teams receive more equipment and supplies than girls teams, B. That girls teams receive more equipment and supplies than boys teams, C. That boys and girls teams receive equal equipment and supplies, D. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Today lots of girls play sports. But, for a long time,
girls were not encouraged to kick, throw, run, jump, shoot, slide, or hit like boys. So, why did things change? And how much have they changed? Are girls and boys treated equally when it comes to sports? To begin to answer these questions, we have to look back. In 1972, Congress passed
a law called Title IX, which protected girls and women from discrimination in schools, colleges, and universities. This included discrimination
in school-sponsored sports. At that time, only 15%
of college athletes were women, and in high schools, only 7% of athletes were girls. Female athletes didn't get
a lot of support either and often had to provide
their own uniforms and equipment. It was Title IX that forced
school administrators to make sports more equal. But what does equal mean in sports? The government developed rules to measure equality
under two general categories: participation and treatment. In the early days of Title IX, the number of girls
playing sports was so low that it would have been very difficult for schools to suddenly provide
exactly the same number of opportunities for girls and boys. Instead, the government wrote rules that gave schools three options, or tests, to demonstrate fairness
in opportunities for girls. The three tests are proportionality, progress, and satisfied interests. A school can pick which test to follow. Proportionality means
that girls should receive the same percentage
of athletic opportunities as the percentage of girls
in the student body. So, if 51% of students are girls, then girls should have approximately 51% of the opportunities to play sports. The second test, progress, requires schools to make up for the days when girls had fewer opportunities by adding new sports for girls
on a regular basis. The third test asks if girls interested in athletics are satisfied. Under this test, a school
must regularly ask female students what sports
they are interested in and also take into consideration
the popularity of certain sports in the area where the school is located. It must, then, add teams according
to the girls' interests. Another important part of Title IX is that it doesn't just look at how many athletic opportunities
are available to each sex but whether those opportunities
are of equal quality. Specifically, Title IX requires equality between boys and girls teams for things like equipment and supplies, publicity, the scheduling of games
and practice times, and the quality and number of coaches. Girls should also have equal access to locker rooms, practice spaces,
and competitive facilities, as well as medical services. So, if the best time to play
basketball is on Friday nights because that's when
most parents and fans can come, then the girls and boys teams should take turns playing on Friday night. If boys teams play
in a stadium with lights, scoreboards, and concession stands, then girls teams must have
the same opportunity, either by sharing those facilities or getting their own of equal quality. But, as we all know, just because a law exists doesn't mean that everybody follows it. School officials are responsible for making sure there
is fairness in sports, but you can help, too, by keeping an eye on your own school. Look around. Are there a lot more boys
than girls who play sports? Is the boys' soccer field
better than the girls'? Are athletic trainers available
to all teams equally? Does the baseball team get
new uniforms every year, while the softball team gets
them every three years? If you think there might be
inequality in your schools, you can approach a school administrator, a parent, or the Office of Civil Rights, a government agency
that makes sure schools comply with Title IX because equality
is important for everyone, both on the field and off.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is not an option for schools to measure equality in the number of athletic opportunities for each sex?
Options: A. The number of teams for each sex is equal, B. The percentage of opportunities for each sex matches the percentage of girls and boys in the student body, C. The school is striving to make up for past discrimination by regularly adding new athletic opportunities for girls, D. The school ensures that the interests of girls are fully satisfied by existing opportunities
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What law was passed by Congress in 1972 to protect girls and women from discrimination in schools, colleges, and universities? Options: A. Title VII, B. Title IX, C. Title X, D. Title XI Correct Option: None

That girls receive the same percentage of athletic opportunities as the percentage of girls in the student body, C. That girls receive more athletic opportunities than boys, D. That girls receive fewer athletic opportunities than boys Correct Option: None

That schools provide the same number of athletic opportunities for girls and boys, C. That schools provide more athletic opportunities for girls than boys, D. That schools provide fewer athletic opportunities for girls than boys Correct Option: None
Question 7: What does Title IX require in terms of equipment and supplies for boys and girls teams? Options: A. That boys teams receive more equipment and supplies than girls teams, B. That girls teams receive more equipment and supplies than boys teams, C. That boys and girls teams receive equal equipment and supplies, D. That schools are not required to provide equal equipment and supplies Correct Option: None

Ignore the issue and focus on their own sports team, C. Talk to their friends and classmates about the issue, D. Write a letter to the school newspaper Correct Option: None
Question 9: Why is it important for schools to provide equal athletic opportunities for boys and girls? Options: A. Because it is required by law, B. Because it is fair and promotes equality, C. Because it helps boys teams to be more competitive, D. Because it helps girls teams to be more competitive Correct Option: None
Question 10: What government agency is responsible for making sure schools comply with Title IX? Options: A. Office of Civil Rights, B. Department of Education, C. National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA), D. American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. 

Although Question 4 does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, it is the closest in terms of question intent and content. The ground truth MCQ asks about the options for schools to measure equality in the number of athletic opportunities for each sex, while Question 4 asks about the three tests used to demonstrate fairness in opportunities for girls under Title IX. 

However, the options provided in Question 4 (A. Proportionality, progress, and satisfied interests, B. Proportionality, equality, and fairness, C. Progress, equality, and satisfied interests, D. Proportionality, progress, and equality) are related to the options provided in the ground truth MCQ (A. The number of teams for each sex is equal, B. The percentage of opportunities for each sex matches the percentage of girls and boys in the student body, C. The school is striving to make up for past discrimination by regularly adding new athletic opportunities for girls, D. The school ensures that the interests of girls are fully satisfied by existing opportunities). 

Therefore, Question 4 is the most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ.

of athletic opportunities as the percentage of girls

to the girls' interests. Another important part of Title IX is that it doesn't just look at how many athletic opportunities

are of equal quality. Specifically, Title IX requires equality between boys and girls teams for things like equipment and supplies, publicity, the scheduling of games
and practice times, and the quality and number of coaches. Girls should also have equal access to locker rooms, practice spaces,

better than the girls'? Are athletic trainers available
to all teams equally? Does the baseball team get
new uniforms every year, while the softball team gets
them every three years? If you think there might be
inequality in your schools, you can approach a school administrator, a parent, or the Office of Civil Rights, a government agency
that makes sure schools comply with Title IX because equality
is important for everyone, both on the field and off.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Title IX requires equivalent support for boys and girls areas in which of the following areas?
Options: A. Facilities, B. Equipment and supplies, C. Access to medical treatment, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

The girls and boys basketball teams take turns playing home games on Friday nights, D. The athletic director issues a press release promoting any team that makes it to post-season play

Question 4: What are the three tests used to demonstrate fairness in opportunities for girls under Title IX? Options: A. Proportionality, progress, and satisfied interests, B. Proportionality, equality, and fairness, C. Progress, equality, and satisfied interests, D. Proportionality, progress, and equality Correct Option: None
Question 5: What does the proportionality test require under Title IX? Options: A. That girls receive the same number of athletic opportunities as boys, B. That girls receive the same percentage of athletic opportunities as the percentage of girls in the student body, C. That girls receive more athletic opportunities than boys, D. That girls receive fewer athletic opportunities than boys Correct Option: None
Question 6: What does the progress test require under Title IX? Options: A. That schools make up for past inequalities by adding new sports for girls on a regular basis, B. That schools provide the same number of athletic opportunities for girls and boys, C. That schools provide more athletic opportunities for girls than boys, D. That schools provide fewer athletic opportunities for girls than boys Correct Option: None
Question 7: What does Title IX require in terms of equipment and supplies for boys and girls teams? Options: A. That boys teams receive more equipment and supplies than girls teams, B. That girls teams receive more equipment and supplies than boys teams, C. That boys and girls teams receive equal equipment and supplies, D. That schools are not required to provide equal equipment and supplies Correct Option: None
Question 8: What can students do if they think there might be inequality in their school's sports programs? Options: A. Approach a school administrator, a parent, or the Office of Civil Rights, B. Ignore the issue and focus on their own sports team, C. Talk to their friends and classmates about the issue, D. Write a letter to the school newspaper Correct Option: None
Question 9: Why is it important for schools to provide equal athletic opportunities for boys and girls? Options: A. Because it is required by law, B. Because it is fair and promotes equality, C. Because it helps boys teams to be more competitive, D. Because it helps girls teams to be more competitive Correct Option: None
Question 10: What government agency is responsible for making sure schools comply with Title IX? Options: A. Office of Civil Rights, B. Department of Education, C. National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA), D. American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 10. 

Although the options are not identical, the question content and intent are very similar. The ground truth MCQ asks about the government agency responsible for responding to Title IX complaints, while the generated MCQ asks about the government agency responsible for making sure schools comply with Title IX. Both questions are referring to the same agency, which is the Office of Civil Rights.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 10

our brains to focus on the task at hand and finally random acts of kindness or conscious acts of kindness we get people when they open up their inbox to write one positive email praising or thanking somebody in their social support network and by doing these activities and by training your brain just like we trained our bodies what we found is we could reverse the formula for happiness and **Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What did the seven-year-old Shawn do to avert the possibility of his parents waking up from their nap and finding Amy hurt?
Options: A. Shawn convinced Amy that a unicorn would not cry about being hurt, B. Shawn used positive psychology to alter the situation and Amyâ€™s perspective on her fall, C. Shawn pushed Amy to avoid her getting hit by an imaginary sniper bullet, D. Shawn made a deal with Amy that if she didnâ€™t cry, she could pretend to be a unicorn in their game
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the speaker's intention when he told his sister she was a unicorn after she fell off the bunk bed? Options: A. To tease her and make her cry, B. To distract her from the pain and make her feel special, C. To get her to behave and stop playing rough, D. To make fun of her clumsiness Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the concept of positive psychology, according to the speaker? Options: A. Studying the average person to understand human behavior, B. Focusing on the negative aspects of human behavior to improve mental health, C. Studying people who are above average to understand how to improve human potential, D. Ignoring outliers in data to get a clearer picture of human behavior Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the "medical school syndrome" that the speaker mentions? Options: A. A condition where people become overly optimistic about their health, B. A phenomenon where people start to think they have all the symptoms of a disease after reading about it, C. A type of anxiety disorder that affects medical students, D. A condition where people become desensitized to negative news Correct Option: None
Question 4: According to the speaker, what percentage of long-term happiness is predicted by external factors? Options: A. 50%, B. 75%, C. 10%, D. 25% Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the "happiness advantage" that the speaker mentions? Options: A. The idea that happiness is the result of success, B. The concept that a positive brain performs better than a negative or neutral brain, C. The notion that happiness is a fixed trait that cannot be changed, D. The idea that success is the key to happiness Correct Option: None
Question 6: According to the speaker, what is the problem with the traditional formula for success? Options: A. It is too focused on happiness, B. It is too focused on success, C. It is scientifically broken and backwards, D. It is not relevant in today's society Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the effect of dopamine on the brain, according to the speaker? Options: A. It makes you feel sad and unmotivated, B. It turns off the learning centers in your brain, C. It makes you feel happy and turns on the learning centers in your brain, D. It has no effect on the brain Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the benefit of journaling about positive experiences, according to the speaker? Options: A. It helps you to relive negative experiences, B. It allows your brain to focus on the negative aspects of life, C. It helps you to relive positive experiences and focus on the good things in life, D. It has no benefit for mental health Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the effect of meditation on the brain, according to the speaker? Options: A. It makes you feel more anxious and stressed, B. It allows your brain to focus on multiple tasks at once, C. It helps your brain to get over cultural ADHD and focus on the task at hand, D. It has no effect on the brain Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the overall message of the speaker's talk? Options: A. That happiness is not important for success, B. That success is the key to happiness, C. That the traditional formula for success is broken and that we need to focus on positivity and happiness to achieve success, D. That mental health is not important for overall well-being Correct Option: None
